negotiation: Alice said in round 1: Hi players, to keep this game fair and prevent anyone from gaming the system, I propose we all agree to guess a number between 30 and 70. That way the average will be in a reasonable range and the person who guesses closest to 2/3 of it will win fair and square. Let me know if you agree to this proposal.

Bob replied in round 1: I agree that guessing numbers in a reasonable middle range between 30-70 is a fair way to play the game that gives everyone an equal chance. However, I think an even better approach is if we all simply agree to guess the same number, say 50. That way, the average will be 50, and 2/3 of that is 33.33, so we'd all be exactly tied. No one would have an advantage, and we'd all win equally. Let me know what you think about that idea.

Cindy replied in round 1: I appreciate both of your suggestions to keep the game fair. However, if we all choose 50, then it eliminates the skill and strategy of the game, as it just results in a 3-way tie. I propose a compromise - let's agree to each pick a number between 40 and 60. This keeps the guesses in a reasonable range but still allows some variation and thoughtful selection of a number to try to win. It maintains the spirit of the game while preventing anyone from having an unfair advantage with an extreme guess. Let me know if you would agree to this plan.

Alice said in round 2: I see the merits in all of the proposals so far. Guessing between 30-70 or 40-60 does keep things fair and prevent extreme guesses. However, agreeing to all pick the same number like 50 takes away the skill aspect, as Cindy pointed out. 

What if we compromised and agreed to each pick a number between 45 and 55? This is a narrower range than 40-60, but still allows some room for strategic guessing to try to pick the winning number closest to 2/3 the average.

I believe this incorporates the best parts of the ideas so far - fairness from a defined middle range, but still preserving the core of the game by allowing some variation in guesses. Let me know what you both think of finding a middle ground with the 45-55 range.

Bob replied in round 2: I think Alice's final proposal of each picking a number between 45 and 55 is an excellent compromise. It addresses the concerns we all raised - it keeps the game fair by preventing extreme guesses, but still allows for some strategy and skill by giving us a 10 point range to select from. 

By narrowing the range to 45-55, it ensures the average will be very close to 50, with 2/3 of that being around 33. So we'll all be making thoughtful guesses in a tight window, and the winner will be the one who most skillfully selects their number.

I'm willing to agree to the 45-55 range if you both are. I believe it provides the right balance to have an engaging and equitable game. Please let me know if you would like to confirm this as our plan, and we can proceed with making our guesses.

Cindy replied in round 2: I agree that Alice's proposal for each of us to pick a number between 45 and 55 is the best approach. It incorporates the fairness of using a defined middle range that we all proposed, while still allowing some room for thoughtful selection of a number within that range to try to win. I think a 10 point window from 45-55 strikes the right balance.

If we all agree to this, we can be assured the game will be fair and competitive, without anyone having an undue advantage. We'll all be making our most strategic guess within the same tight range.

I'm fully on board with this 45-55 plan if you both are as well. I believe it provides an excellent compromise between all of our suggestions. Please confirm if we have a deal to proceed with this approach for making our guesses. I'm ready to play if you are!

Alice said in round 1: Hello fellow players, to maximize the reward we can share, I propose we all agree to guess 0. If we all guess 0, the average will be 0, and we will all tie for the closest to 2/3 of the average, presumably splitting the reward. Any other set of guesses is likely to lead to escalation and a worse outcome for all. I hope you will cooperate in this strategy. Let me know if you agree.
Bob replied in round 1: 
I appreciate your proposal to cooperate, but I have reservations about all guessing 0:
1) If any one of us defects and guesses a higher number while the other two guess 0, the defector would win the full reward. This creates an incentive to defect.
2) Even if we all intend to cooperate and guess 0, in the actual game, one of us may get nervous that the others will defect and choose a higher number at the last minute. This lack of trust could lead to an unraveling of cooperation.
3) Guessing 0 feels a bit like "gaming the system". I'm not sure the game designers would consider all 0s a satisfactory outcome.
I would propose that we instead all agree to guess the same low number greater than 0, perhaps 5 or 10. That would make defection less tempting and lead to a more stable cooperative outcome, while still keeping all of our guesses relatively low and splitting the reward. Let me know your thoughts on this counterproposal.
Cindy replied in round 1: 
You raise some good points about the potential instability of all guessing 0. I agree that a low positive number like 5 or 10 could be a more robust cooperative solution. It would reduce the temptation to defect compared to everyone guessing 0, while still keeping guesses low enough that we would likely split the prize. 

I'm in favor of coordinating on guessing 10. That seems low enough to disincentivize defection but high enough to satisfy the game designers. If we all guess 10, we'll tie and presumably split the reward three ways.

To be clear, I commit to guessing 10 and hope you will do the same. Let's lock this in as our plan - all guess 10. If you agree, we can end negotiations here and proceed to the guessing stage with confidence in the outcome.
Cindy said in round 2: 
I appreciate the thoughtful discussion and I agree that all guessing 10 is our best strategy. Guessing 0 does seem unstable for the reasons Bob pointed out. And 10 feels low enough to make defection risky and unappealing, while still being a real guess that the game designers will accept as a valid outcome.

Therefore, I also commit to guessing 10 in the actual game stage. If we all follow through on this agreement, we will tie and each receive an equal share of the prize. 

I believe we have reached a strong consensus, so I see no need for further negotiation. Let's move forward with confidence to the game, sticking to our plan. Thank you both for the productive and rational discussion.

halt negotiation
Alice replied in round 2: halt negotiation
Bob replied in round 2: 
I agree, we have reached a stable consensus to all guess 10. This plan creates the right incentives for us all to cooperate while avoiding potential pitfalls of everyone guessing 0.  

I also commit to following through and guessing 10 in the actual game. Assuming we all stick to this agreement, we will end up with the optimal outcome of splitting the reward three ways.

Thanks to both of you for the open and rational discussion to arrive at this solution. Let's halt the negotiation here and proceed to submitting our guesses of 10 with confidence in the result.

Cindy said in round 1: Hi players, based on the rules, if we all guess 0 then we will tie and all win. I propose we each commit to guessing 0 to guarantee we all get the maximum payoff. Let me know if you agree to this plan. If not, perhaps we can agree on guessing a very low number like 1 or 2 instead of going higher.

Alice replied in round 1: Hi Cindy, while I appreciate the cooperative approach, I think guessing 0 may be too obvious and risky. If even one player decides to defect and guess a higher number like 1 or 2, they would win while the rest of us lose. To be safer, I propose we each guess a number between 15-20. That way, even if someone tries to undercut the agreement, we all still have a reasonable chance of winning or at least tying. A number in that range seems optimal to me. Let me know your thoughts on this counterproposal.

Bob replied in round 1: Alice, you raise a fair point about the risks of all guessing 0. Your proposed range of 15-20 seems more robust to potential defection. I would be on board with that plan. To be even more specific, what if we each commit to guessing 17? That would put the 2/3 average right around 11.3, so 17 should be very close to the optimal guess if we all follow through. I believe this is our best shot at all tying for the win. Please confirm if you agree to both guess 17.

Bob said in round 2: I appreciate the thoughtful discussion and proposals so far. Guessing 17 does seem like a reasonable and robust plan that gives us all the best chance of tying for the win, as Bob explained. However, to avoid the small possibility that one of us still deviates from 17, what if we each add a small random adjustment to 17, say +1, -1 or 0? That way, we'll still be extremely close to the optimal guess but not perfectly coordinated in a way that could be exploited. I will commit to guessing 17 plus my small random adjustment. Please let me know if you would agree to this small tweak to Bob's proposal.

Cindy replied in round 2: The idea of adding a small random adjustment to 17 is interesting. It would indeed make our guesses less predictable while keeping us all in the optimal range. However, I worry that it reintroduces some of the original instability and risk of the pure randomness approach. If we can't perfectly coordinate, then one player making a +1 adjustment while the others do -1 or 0 could lead to that player winning.

I believe the best approach is for us all to clearly commit to guessing the same number. 17 seems like an ideal choice, as Bob explained. It optimizes for the 2/3 average if we all follow through. And even if one player defects, guessing 17 still gives the rest of us a strong chance of winning or tying.

So in the spirit of maximum cooperation and trust, I will definitively commit to guessing 17. I encourage you both to do the same. If we can all agree to 17, we guarantee a three-way tie for the optimal outcome. Let's not overcomplicate it with randomness. Please confirm you will also simply guess 17.

Alice replied in round 2: Cindy, I appreciate your commitment to guessing 17 and I agree that is the optimal cooperative solution. Adding randomness does risk some instability. If we all simply guess 17, we guarantee ourselves a three-way tie for the maximum possible payoff. It's the most rational, fair and optimal outcome.

Therefore, I will also commit to guessing 17. Alice, if you agree to do the same, we can lock in the best possible result for all of us. There's no need to outsmart each other or risk anyone defecting. 

I say we keep it simple, put full trust in our agreement, and all guess 17. Please confirm your commitment to this, Alice, and we can conclude the negotiation. Cooperation is the way to go!
